DOCNAME: HEADLEY AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
TEXT: The first applicant , Mr Prince PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and is currently detained in GPE . The second applicant , PERSON , is a NORP citizen , born in DATE who currently lives in GPE .
The applicants were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a solicitor practising in GPE , and ORG . The respondent Government were represented by Ms. PERSON , ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The first applicant claims that he ran a successful record promoting business in GPE , GPE which , he alleges , drew the attention of gangs , who demanded to become involved . When he refused to continue sharing profits with the gang , on DATE the first applicant was shot in the face by gang members and was admitted to hospital suffering with paralysis of the left side of his face . On DATE gang members forced their way into his home in the early morning and shot at the applicant and his girlfriend , PERSON . The first applicant was readmitted to ORG at TIME with multiple gun shot wounds , to the right jaw - bone , the left forearm and right arm , to the right “ axillary fold ” , the tip of the right shoulder and to the right side of his chest . CARDINAL of the bullets intended for him hit PERSON , who was fatally injured and died , aged DATE , on DATE .

The first applicant alleges that he had to be kept under police protection in hospital , and that at CARDINAL point gang members attempted to enter the hospital to kill him , in order to destroy evidence relating to PERSON murder . CARDINAL of the gang members , a cousin of PERSON , was subsequently convicted of a firearms offence and sentenced to a determinate period of imprisonment . According to the first applicant , he has now been released from prison .

The first applicant did not give evidence at the trial . In DATE the first applicant , whose mother is a NORP citizen , entered GPE on DATE medical visa , to allow him to gain treatment for his gunshot injuries . This visa was subsequently extended until DATE .

In DATE the first applicant visited GPE to see his grandfather , who was terminally ill . In DATE he again travelled to GPE , for his grandfather 's funeral . He claims that he was shot at by gang members , and had to return to GPE after a stay of DATE . He has not been back to GPE since .

The first applicant claims he set up a business in the GPE importing clothing from continental LOC . He has been married twice in GPE . On the basis of his first marriage in DATE he was granted , on DATE , leave to remain for DATE . The marriage broke down – although it produced a daughter ( born DATE ) , with whom he still has some contact – and he did not apply for indefinite leave to remain .

The first applicant claims that in DATE he started a relationship with the C. The couple had a child together , R , born on DATE . Although they were married on DATE , it does not appear that their relationship was continuous in the meantime .
On DATE the applicant was joined from GPE by his son PERSON , the second applicant , who was born on DATE , and is the younger son of PERSON . His older brother still lives in GPE .

Upon arriving in GPE the second applicant was given DATE extended leave to remain . The first applicant claims that the second applicant lived with him until he was imprisoned . However , it is not clear who else was living with the first applicant at the time . At the time of his arrest in DATE the first applicant said he was living with a girlfriend by the name of “ PERSON ” .

The first applicant appears to have remained in prison from the time of this arrest in DATE until the time of his trial in DATE . On DATE the first appellant was convicted of conspiracy to import a Class A drug and sentenced to DATE imprisonment and a GBP CARDINAL confiscation order . He had made several trips to and from GPE , CARDINAL of them in the company of a woman who was arrested when re - entering GPE with QUANTITY of cocaine hidden in her vagina . It is not clear whom the second applicant lived with while the first applicant was in prison . On DATE a person by the name of PERSON made an application for indefinite leave to remain on behalf of the second applicant . In that application she described herself as the second applicant 's “ stepmother ” . On DATE , ORG recorded in a social work assessment that the second applicant was living with a “ family friend ” . However , it is accepted by the Government that by the time of this application to the court , in DATE , the second applicant was living with C and NORP

The trial judge did not recommend that the applicant be deported , but the Secretary of ORG nonetheless , because of the drugs conviction , made a deportation order against him on DATE . The first applicant appealed against this decision and claimed asylum , on the basis that he would risk violence from gang members if returned to GPE . On DATE the Secretary of ORG decided to refuse asylum and to refuse to revoke the deportation order . On DATE the decision was made to give directions for the first applicant 's removal . The first applicant appealed against these decisions under Part CARDINAL of ORG ( see below ) . His appeals were dealt with jointly and refused by an adjudicator on DATE , after a hearing at which the first applicant represented himself . The first applicant did not seek permission to appeal that decision to ORG .

On DATE the ORG set directions for the removal of the first applicant on DATE . The first applicant was nominally released from imprisonment on DATE but was immediately detained by the immigration authorities pending deportation . However , the deportation was stayed pending the outcome of this application and on DATE the first applicant was granted bail on condition that he stay with C.

Around this time the first applicant discovered that C was in a relationship with another man . It was alleged that he made violent threats against this other man and on DATE he was remanded back into custody on charges of possessing an illegal firearm and making unlawful threats . These charges were subsequently dismissed . However , C has since indicated that she no longer wishes to have contact with the first applicant .

When the first applicant returned to prison , in DATE , the second applicant moved in with C 's brother , ORG 's partner and their daughter . He has lived there ever since . S has indicated that the second applicant can stay there “ forever DATE or as long as he wants ” .
The Government have not yet made any decision as to whether or not they intend to remove the second applicant .

The applicants have submitted various reports in relation to the second applicant . A letter from the head teacher of his junior school states that he has slight learning difficulties and would find it difficult to adjust to any further changes in his life . In DATE the second applicant started at secondary school . A letter from his current head teacher , dated DATE , states that the second applicant has behaved aggressively at school . However , according to ORG 's witness statement , dated DATE , the second applicant 's behaviour at school “ stabilised ” after he moved in with ORG 's family in DATE .

CARDINAL reports were prepared in connection with the present application by PERSON , a chartered psychologist . The first report appears to have been based on various false assumptions , such as that the second applicant lived as part of a “ nuclear family ” with the first applicant and C for DATE ( DATE ) .

The second report , dated DATE , contains the following conclusions : ( CARDINAL ) there were CARDINAL consistent factors in the second applicant 's life : his father and his black NORP identity ; ( CARDINAL ) it is in the second applicant 's interests to maintain both ; ( CARDINAL ) the second applicant 's sense of security and family has been maintained by living with S and his partner – “ an extremely positive solution to what could have been an extremely negative situation ” .

Part CARDINAL of ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ) provided that anyone who was the subject of an immigration decision , such as a decision to make or refuse a deportation order or a decision to set removal directions , should have a right of appeal to an adjudicator if they alleged that that decision was in breach of their rights under either ORG ( “ FAC ) or LAW relating to LAW .

The appeal provisions in Part CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act were later repealed by the Nationality , Immigration and Asylum Act CARDINAL ( “ the DATE Act ” ) . Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act brought in new appeal provisions , which did not , however , have effect in relation to any events which took place before DATE . For all such events the appeal provisions under Part CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act continued to have effect .
Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act provides as follows :
“ A party to an appeal to an adjudicator under section DATE or DATE may , with the permission of ORG , appeal to the ORG against the adjudicator 's determination on a point of law . ”
Paragraph CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of Schedule CARDINAL to the Nationality , Immigration and Asylum Act DATE ( Commencement No . CARDINAL ) Order DATE ( as amended ) provides as follows :

“ LAW ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act shall apply to a party to an appeal to an adjudicator under LAW which is determined on or after CARDINALth DATE , as it applies to a party to an appeal to an adjudicator under section CARDINAL or CARDINAL . ”

Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE provides that , in determining any question that arises in connection with a Convention right , courts and tribunals must have regard to all relevant case law from this ORG .

In the case of R v ORG ex p ORG ( ( DATE ) EWHC CARDINAL Admin ) , ORG held that , in determining appeals relating to LAW , adjudicators and tribunals were obliged to consider the rights under LAW of the appellant 's family as well as the appellant himself .

ORG and ORG v Secretary of ORG for ORG ( [ DATE ] INLR DATE ) concerned a GPE national , who was given permission to visit GPE for DATE in DATE . DATE he married a NORP citizen and was given indefinite leave to remain . In DATE a son was born to their marriage . In DATE Mr ORG was convicted of being knowingly concerned with the importation of QUANTITY of cocaine worth GBP CARDINAL and was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . While in prison he behaved as a model prisoner and it was accepted by the Secretary of ORG that he was unlikely to re - offend . Nonetheless the Secretary of ORG made an order that he be deported , relying in particular on the importance of deportation as a deterrent to actual and prospective drug traffickers . Mr ORG appealed against this decision . In finding against him ORG held that the Secretary of ORG had been entitled to attach importance to his general policy of deporting those convicted of importation of class A drugs in order to protect those resident in GPE from the harmful effect of drugs and , by deterring others , in the interests of preventing crime and disorder .
